body: If a capture has a high analysis label and the user finishes the capture and then leaves the app before the loading is complete. A error occurs in which the AI capture has failed. Ideally this would not happen. Might require a server to do a back up catch The client is not available.
title: Analysis fail on user exits app

body: The question and procedure sections of the issue should eventually be collaborative so that if paired with a technician they can get improtant information before showing up. it could also be used as a live quote with estimated duration for steps and cost brakedown.
title: Chat with technicians on issues

body: If there are blocking questions, then they should block the generation of the procedure so that the ai doesn't go barking up the wrong tree. This relates to the GitHub Issue about modifying questions to have the answers be pre defined so the user just has to select the relevant answers. Questions should be critical for determining the type of procedure. Asking if they have the color of paint to fix the chipped wall is not a good question because it should instead be a procedure item that occurs after the identification of the color of paint. If the user already has it then they can immediately check off the step in the procedure.
title: Questions before procedure

body: if a capture is typed as an issue then it will create an issue instance, the data is sent to the ai with a tailored promt, any required questions will be generated, and eventually a procedure with required items is generated. If it is typed as inventory, then the ai will identify the items in the image and those items will be added to the inventory or have the quantity updated. A cleaning type might be a sub type of an issue and not change the structure but just be appended to the data sent to the ai helping it understand the context.
title: Typed capture dictates flow

body: send AI the users inventory for reuse of tags.
title: Send inventory tags to llm as context

body:
behavioural + layout consistency:
	•	Event handling – Every list cell currently re-implements onPress, onSwipe, “long-press to multi-select”, etc. A single <ListItem> HOC lets you wire those once and pass the variant (Issue / To-Do / To-Get) as props.
	•	Spacing & typography – Even with a shared colour/radius token, padding and font sizes vary (check commit a2f6…) and that breaks visual rhythm.
	•	Future refactors – When you introduce animated reorder or drag-and-drop, doing it in one wrapper is dramatically simpler.
title: List component

body:
## Trade:
<head></head>
Pros | Cons
-- | --
Far fewer “camera killed” events on Android | Requires eject’ing if you’re on Expo’s managed workflow
Ultra‑low latency previews & flexible frame processing | Larger native footprint, more dependencies
First‑class support for advanced vision/ML use cases | Slightly steeper install & upgrade path

## Process
- Setup & Install: (eject, pods, 
- API Rewrite (replace preview, capture flow, adapt taps)
- Frame Processor Worklets (optional)

body:
## no 
- Confusion: users might not understand what they are filtering if they see material/equipment tags
- Clutter: The tag suggestions are great if typing ~2-3 characters results in the tag the user's desired tag, if the tags are mixed then bunch of cleaning products might get suggested when the user wants to see locations

## yes
- There is no other place to find them
- It answers the question of: why do we need this item on the To get list?

## decision
We should make it possible to filter issues by the tags on their procedure item tags
- Make an enhancement issue to implement: IssueList filter to accept equipment/material tags; equipment/material tags should be displayed in their unique color to differentiate
- Make an enhancement issue to implement: ListScreen link to IssueList filter; Link from ListScreen To Get item to a filter for that material/equipment tag in the issueList screen.
title: Should the IssueList filter accept equipment/material tags?

body:
What should the project guidence be for when to make or use a GitHub label, milestone, or project? 
## Label
- Unique to repository
- Multiple can be assigned to an issue
### Use Cases of labels
- Categorize: Action required

## Milestone
- One per issue
- Time bound
- Can be linked to pull requests
- Issues can be prioritized with-in the milestone
### Use Cases of Milestones
- Sprints
- Work packages

## Project
- Issue can be assigned to multiple projects (I think)
- Issue have [fields](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/understanding-fields) unique to project
- Can group issues and pull requests
- Use views to save preset filters
- Can have [iterations](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/understanding-fields/about-iteration-fields)?
- Can have [road maps](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/planning-and-tracking-with-projects/customizing-views-in-your-project/customizing-the-roadmap-layout)
### Use Cases of projects
- Allow independent working groups 
- Should include field that indicates how a Project is a stakeholder in the issue (RACI)
title: When to use a milestone vs. a label vs. a project

body:
GitHub, Jira, Trello, etc. could be the web interface for facilities to manage, delegate, and resolve issues. This would reduce the development burden significantly. 
GitHub is my preference because of CLI, possibly to store procedures as documents, scripts, or "Actions".

## Potential trade criteria 
- Object management 
- API
- web interface 
- Mobile app
- Pricing
- Longevity/maintaince
title: How could an existing service be the web interface for facilities?

body:
Issues from customers, passersby, and other transient stakeholders face the issue of routing them to the responsible party. Renters may be able to hand over an export of the issues but it could be rejected because it wasn't submitted through the established portal. 
Capturing the location of the issue means it is possible to find the owner of the land and potentially the responsible party of the facility by sending mail, internet sleuthing, and the like. 
For a service like this to be dominant it would need an api and web app for facility managers to tap into to view and triage issues.
title: Is it worth it to capture non-resident issues

body: Is it possible to have enough people on the app and capturing issues so that a technician that is going to be in the area is provided with a menu of jobs that they could pair to maximize time being paid versus travel, sales, etc. With Al of the prerequisite questions, material, and equipment identified and maybe already acquired.
title: How to maximize technicians time

body: Issues of items like software and things that can move or be moved. This requires knowing the responsible party (implicitly or explicitly) and vendor/manufacturer.
title: Non-facility issues worth it?

chores" and  "cleaning" could be selected as tags so that all issues captured in that session would be tagged as chores and cleaning.
